## Gap of Mediation Model for Exposomics

### Omics enable the analysis of multiple molecules at the same time

### Redundant information matters

- For analytical chemists, not all measured molecules can be identified

- For biochemist, not all identified compounds are related to each other

- For environmental scientist, not all molecules are related to exposures or health outcomes

> We can't build a model with better accuracy than measurement

### GlobalStd Algorithm Step 1

- Retention time cluster analysis

```{r echo=FALSE,out.width = "500px"}
library(rmwf)
data(mzrt)
mzrtm <- enviGCMS::getdoe(mzrt)
gm <- mzrtm$groupmean
gr <- mzrtm$grouprsd
# filter data
srm <- grepl('NIST',colnames(gm))
blk <- grepl('Matrix',colnames(gm))
indexmean <- apply(gm,1,function(x) all(x[srm]>= 3*x[blk]))
mzrtfilter <- enviGCMS::getfilter(mzrt,rowindex = indexmean)
mzrtnist <- enviGCMS::getfilter(mzrt,rowindex = indexmean,colindex = grepl('NIST',colnames(mzrt$data)))
pmd <- pmd::getpaired(mzrtnist)
pmd::plotrtg(pmd)
```

---
### GlobalStd Algorithm Step 2

- High frequency PMD analysis across RT clusters

```{r echo=FALSE,out.width = "500px"}
pmd::plotpaired(pmd)
```

---

### GlobalStd Algorithm Step 2

- High frequency PMD analysis across RT clusters - example

- Based on data itself, those adducts/multiply charged ions/neutral loss/isotopologues can be unknown

### GlobalStd Algorithm Step 3

- Independent peaks selection


- Independent peaks selection - example

```{r echo=FALSE,out.width = "500px"}

pmd::plotstdrt(std,rtcluster = 44,main = 'Retention time group 44')
pmd::plotstdrt(std,rtcluster = 103,main = 'Retention time group 103')
pmd::plotstdrt(std,rtcluster = 1,main = 'Retention time group 1')
```

## Quantitative and Qualitative analysis in Reactomics

- Reaction: $S_1 + S_2 + … + S_n = P_1 + P_2 + … + P_m \ (n>=1,m>=1)$

- PMD matrix

```{r render= 'asis'}
C1 <- c('\\(|S_1 - P_1|\\)','\\(|S_2 - P_1|\\)','...','\\(|S_n - P_1|\\)')
C2 <- c('\\(|S_1 - P_2|\\)','\\(|S_2 - P_2|\\)','...','\\(|S_n - P_2|\\)')
C3 <- c('...','...','...','...')
Cm <- c('\\(|S_1 - P_m|\\)','\\(|S_2 - P_m|\\)','...','\\(|S_n - P_m|\\)')

tb <- rbind.data.frame(C1,C2,C3,Cm)
colnames(tb) <- c('\\(S_1\\)','\\(S_2\\)','...','\\(S_n\\)')
rownames(tb) <- c('\\(P_1\\)','\\(P_2\\)','...','\\(P_m\\)')
tb <- knitr::kable(tb, align="c",format = 'html',row.names = T,escape = F)
tb <- gsub("`", "", tb) 
tb
```

- Paired mass distances for certain parent compound:

$$PMD_{S_{k}} = min(|S_k-P_1|,|S_k-P_2|,...,|S_k-P_m|) (1 \le k \le n )$$
- Paired mass distances for certain reaction:

$$PMD_R = \{PMD_{S_{1}}, PMD_{S_{2}},...,PMD_{S_{n}}\}$$

### Quantitative and Qualitative analysis in Reactomics (Static v.s. dynamic)

- Static mass pairs: paired intensity ratio is stable across samples
- Dynamic mass pairs: paired intensity ratio is not stable across samples
- For example, [A,B], [C,D] and [E,F] are involved in the same PMD:

```{r}
GroupI <- c(100,50,'2:1',100,50,'2:1', 30,40, '3:4')
GroupII <- c(1000,500,'2:1',10,95,'2:19',120,160,'3:4' )
df <- rbind.data.frame(GroupI,GroupII)
colnames(df) <- c('A','B','Ins ratio','C','D','Ins ratio','E','F','Ins ratio')
knitr::kable(df,align = 'c',format = 'markdown')
```

- [A,B] and [E,F] are static mass pairs so can be used in quantitative analysis, rsd cutoff 30%
- [C,D] can be used to check dynamics of a specific reaction

## Adolescent girls blood samples

- #### Breast Cancer and the Environment Research Program (BCERP) 

- #### 152 girls with data on exposures, health outcomes, and potential confounding variables 

- #### **Exposures** measured by CDC
  - PFCs (n-PFOS, Sm-PFOS, n-PFOA, PFHxS, PFNA)
  - trace elements (BCD, Cadmium; BMN, Manganese; BPBLead, Lead; BSE, Selenium; THG, Mercury) 

- #### **Metabolomics** by LC-Q-TOF-MS
  - 18750 (ZHP) and 25937 (RPN) features were found in plasma samples

- #### **Health outcomes**
  - BMI/BMI group
  - age at menarche

---

### Step 1: Correlation clusters among metabolites

```{r echo=FALSE,out.width='70%'}
knitr::include_graphics('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/yufree/presentation/gh-pages/figure/cutoffselection.png')
```

- Remove redundant peaks by GlobalStd algorithm (18750 to 964)
- 0.82 was selected as cutoff for AMN

---

### Step 1: Correlation clusters among metabolites

```{r echo=FALSE,out.width='60%'}
knitr::include_graphics('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/yufree/presentation/gh-pages/figure/amn2.png')
```

- 109 metabolites correlation network clusters found
- 555 out of 964 metabolites have no correlation with other metabolites

## The Long Island Breast Cancer Study Project

- #### 100 plasma samples with data on lifestyle, health outcomes, and potential confounding variables 

- #### **lifestyle** is from questionnaire
  - Alcohol, smoking, meat consumption, vegetable, fruit, physical activity, supplementary
  
- #### **Metabolomics** by LC-Q-TOF-MS
  - 6615 (ZHP) and 5171 (RPN) features were found in plasma samples
  - 1797 peaks were selected as surrogate peaks for metabolites

- #### **Health outcomes** with co-variables
  - 50 cases and 50 controls 
  - BMI, income, education, reproductive variables

# Summary

---

## Summary

### Molecular can mediate the influnces from exposure to health conditions

### Mass sepctrometry based molecular data contain reduncdant features

### Paired mass distances can be used to filter reaction level information

### Correlation based network can be used to filter metabolites sensitive to exposure

### Active molecular network can be used reveal the mechanism between exposures and health outcomes
